title: Trump wins the chyron war with Biden
text:
The media’s reaction to Trump’s China comments is a particularly dramatic example of what some writers and media specialists have discerned as a key to the president’s successful communications: He understands that readers no longer consume entire articles or watch lengthy news discussions. Rather, they pick up stray impressions from what they see or hear on the go, which then add up to concrete ideas that may not fully comport with facts or reality.

Even if media organizations go to pains to describe Trump’s allegations about Biden as “unsupported” or “unsubstantiated,” it may not be enough to prevent those impressions from being made — as New York Times columnist Michelle Goldberg argued this week.

“It suggests more muddiness in the factual record than actually exists,” she wrote. “Trump isn’t making unproven charges against Biden. He is blatantly lying about him. He and his defenders are spreading a conspiracy theory that is the precise opposite of the truth.”

Muddying the waters is a strategy which worked for Trump in 2016 against Hillary Clinton and appears to be part of the playbook against Biden.

Joshua Green, a Bloomberg Businessweek writer and author of a 2017 biography of Trump ally and former Breitbart chief Steve Bannon, wrote Wednesday how Bannon sought to get potentially damaging storylines about Clinton out of the conservative media echo chamber and into the mainstream press. And “as Bannon had intended,” Green wrote, “the whiff of corruption attached itself to Hillary and became a major theme of the media’s coverage, poisoning her image.”

In 2015, Bannon promoted the findings of “Clinton Cash” by Peter Schweizer, a Breitbart editor and president of the Government Accountability Institute, a nonprofit that’s received significant backing from the right-wing Mercer family. The New York Times struck an “exclusive agreement” with Schweizer, resulting in a front-page story highlighting potential conflicts of interest involving the Clinton Foundation.

Schweizer is now making his mark on the presidential election cycle with “Secret Empires,” a 2018 book that examined how “the American political class hides corruption” and highlighted the business activities of Biden’s son Hunter in Ukraine and China.

“As with ‘Clinton Cash,’ Schweizer didn’t allege in his book on the Bidens that any laws were broken,” Green writes. “Instead, his reporting laid out a suggestive timeline that led readers to the inescapable conclusion that what had transpired reeked of influence-peddling and moral, if not legal, corruption — the sort of self-dealing voters despise.”

It’s fair to question Hunter Biden taking a high-paying directorship at Burisma Holdings in Ukraine, or conducting other international business, while his father was vice president, as journalists did several years ago. Former New York Times reporter James Risen wrote in 2015 how the son’s business relationships could undermine his father’s “anticorruption message” in Ukraine.

But Risen didn’t accuse Joe Biden of impropriety, as is now being alleged. Risen last week wrote that Trump, his lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, and allies of having “twisted, perverted, and turned” his journalism into “lies and poisonous propaganda.”

Trump and Giuliani have mentioned China in connection to the Bidens several times in recent weeks, though the story hasn’t gotten significant traction beyond conservative media ecosystem, which includes Fox News opinion hosts.

The Daily Beast’s Lachlan Markay and Asawin Suebsaeng wrote on Sept. 26 how Bannon, Schweizer and others were trying to “open a new front” around the China allegations, though “their efforts have come as almost all of the national political attention is focused” around Ukraine.

In “Secret Empires,” Schweizer looked at Hunter Biden’s role in investment fund BHR Partners, which struck a deal with the Chinese government-owned Bank of China shortly after Hunter Biden and his daughter accompanied Joe Biden on a 2013 trip to meet President Xi Jinping.

In a July profile in The New Yorker, Hunter Biden acknowledged meeting with a BHR representative, though dismissed it as a social call. “How do I go to Beijing, halfway around the world, and not see them for a cup of coffee?” he said.

The New Yorker also noted that Hunter Biden “became an unpaid member of BHR’s board but did not take an equity stake in BHR Partners until after his father left the White House.”

Such nuance was missing from Trump’s unfounded claim that “what happened in China is just about as bad as what happened with Ukraine” — a line that immediately became part of the Fox News chyron: “Trump: China Should Investigate Bidens, What Happened There Just About As Bad As What Happened In Ukraine."

Nonetheless, that was only a little more amped up than what viewers saw on liberal MSNBC: "Trump Calls For Ukraine, China To Investigate.”

And while news organizations continued to work the story throughout the day, focusing mainly on Trump, Biden felt obliged to issue a stinging defense of his family, thereby shifting at least some of the spotlight to him, which is probably what Trump sought to provoke in the first place.

Trump’s strategy, concluded journalist and author Michael Weiss on Twitter Thursday, was to sell “debunked lies to the base” and force “the media to keep mentioning and re-litigating Biden/Burisma (and now China) while denouncing the media as enemy agents.”
